subsection.title: The Definition of Function
subsection.p: We often want to predict values of one variable from the values of a related variable. For example, when a physician prescribes a drug in a certain dosage, she needs to know how long the dose will remain in the bloodstream. A sales manager needs to know how the price of his product will affect its sales. A functionfunction is a special type of relationship between variables that allows us to make such predictions.

assemblage.title: Definition of Function
assemblage.p: A functionfunction is a relationship between two variables for which a unique value of the outputoutput variable can be determined from a value of the inputinput variable.

subsection.p: What distinguishes functions from other variable relationships? The definition of a function calls for a unique value— that is, exactly one value of the output variable corresponding to each value of the input variable. This property makes functions useful in applications because they can often be used to make predictions.

li.p: The distance, d, traveled by a car in 2 hours is a function of its speed, r. If we know the speed of the car, we can determine the distance it travels by the formula d = r \cdot 2.

The cost of a fill-up with unleaded gasoline is a function of the number of gallons purchased. The gas pump represents the function by displaying the corresponding values of the input variable (number of gallons) and the output variable (cost).

Score on the Scholastic Aptitude Test (SAT) is not a function of score on an IQ test, because two people with the same score on an IQ test may score differently on the SAT; that is, a person’s score on the SAT is not uniquely determined by his or her score on an IQ test.

subsection.p: A function can be described in several different ways. In the following examples, we consider functions defined by tables, by graphs, and by equations.

subsection.title: Functions Defined by Tables
subsection.p: When we use a table to describe a function, the first variable in the table (the left column of a vertical table or the top row of a horizontal table) is the input variable, and the second variable is the output. We say that the output variable is a function of the input.

li.p: shows data on sales compiled over several years by the accounting office for Eau Claire Auto Parts, a division of Major Motors. In this example, the year is the input variable, and total sales is the output. We say that total sales, S, is a function of t.
gives the cost of sending printed material by first-class mail in 2016.

If we know the weight of the article being shipped, we can determine the required postage from . For instance, a catalog weighing 4.5 ounces would require 1.31 in postage. In this example, w is the input variable and p is the output variable. We say that p is a function of w.
records the age and cholesterol count for 20 patients tested in a hospital survey.

According to these data, cholesterol count is not a function of age, because several patients who are the same age have different cholesterol levels. For example, three different patients are 51 years old but have cholesterol counts of 227, 209, and 216, respectively. Thus, we cannot determine a unique value of the output variable (cholesterol count) from the value of the input variable (age). Other factors besides age must influence a person’s cholesterol count.

subsection.title: Functions Defined by Graphs
subsection.p: A graph may also be used to define one variable as a function of another. The input variable is displayed on the horizontal axis, and the output variable on the vertical axis.

statement.p: shows the number of hours, H, that the sun is above the horizon in Peoria, Illinois, on day t, where January 1 corresponds to t = 0.

li.p: Which variable is the input, and which is the output?
Approximately how many hours of sunlight are there in Peoria on day 150?
On which days are there 12 hours of sunlight?
What are the maximum and minimum values of H, and when do these values occur?
The input variable, t, appears on the horizontal axis. The number of daylight hours, H, is a function of the date. The output variable appears on the vertical axis.
The point on the curve where t = 150 has H \approx 14.1, so Peoria gets about 14.1 hours of daylight when t = 150, which is at the end of May.
H = 12 at the two points where t \approx 85 (in late March) and t \approx 270 (late September).

The maximum value of 14.4 hours occurs on the longest day of the year, when t \approx 170, about three weeks into June. The minimum of 9.6 hours occurs on the shortest day, when t \approx 355, about three weeks into December.

subsection.title: Functions Defined by Equations
subsection.p: illustrates a function defined by an equation.

example.p: As of 2016, One World Trade Center in New York City is the nation’s tallest building, at 1776 feet. If an algebra book is dropped from the top of One World Trade Center, its height above the ground after t seconds is given by the equation h = 1776 - 16t^2 Thus, after \alert{1} second the book’s height is h = 1776 - 16(\alert{1})^2 = 1760 \text{ feet} After \alert{2} seconds its height is h = 1776 - 16(\alert{2})^2 = 1712 \text{ feet} For this function, t is the input variable and h is the output variable. For any value of t, a unique value of h can be determined from the equation for h. We say that h is a function of t.

subsection.title: Function Notation
subsection.p: There is a convenient notation for discussing functions. First, we choose a letter, such as f, g, or h (or F, G, or H), to name a particular function. (We can use any letter, but these are the most common choices.) For instance, the height, h, of a falling textbook is a function of the elapsed time, t. We might call this function f. In other words, f is the name of the relationship between the variables h and t. We write h = f (t) which means "h is a function of t, and f is the name of the function."

warning.p: The new symbol f(t), read "f of t," is another name for the height, h. The parentheses in the symbol f(t) do not indicate multiplication. (It would not make sense to multiply the name of a function by a variable.) Think of the symbol f(t) as a single variable that represents the output value of the function.

subsection.p: With this new notation we may write h = f (t) = 1776 - 16t^2 or just f (t) = 1776 - 16t^2 instead of h = 1776 - 16t^2 to describe the function.
Perhaps it seems complicated to introduce a new symbol for h, but the notation f(t) is very useful for showing the correspondence between specific values of the variables h and t.

example.p: In , the height of an algebra book dropped from the top of One World Trade Center is given by the equation h = 1776 - 16t^2 We see that
Using function notation, these relationships can be expressed more concisely as

which we read as "f of 1 equals 1760" and "f of 2 equals 1712." The values for the input variable, t, appear inside the parentheses, and the values for the output variable, h, appear on the other side of the equation.

subsection.p: Remember that when we write y = f(x), the symbol f(x) is just another name for the output variable.

subsection.title: Evaluating a Function
subsection.p: Finding the value of the output variable that corresponds to a particular value of the input variable is called evaluating the functionevaluating the function.

statement.p: Let g be the name of the postage function defined by in . Find g(1), g(3), and g(6.75).

solution.p:
when w=1,
p=0.47 so g(1)=0.47
when w=3,
p=0.89 so g(3)=0.89
when w=6.75,
p=1.73 so g(6.75)=1.73
Thus, a letter weighing 1 ounce costs 0.47 to mail, a letter weighing 3 ounces costs 0.89, and a letter weighing 6.75 ounces costs 1.73.

subsection.p: If a function is described by an equation, we simply substitute the given input value into the equation to find the corresponding output, or function value.
To simplify the notation, we sometimes use the same letter for the output variable and for the name of the function. In the next example, C is used in this way.

statement.p: TrailGear decides to market a line of backpacks. The cost, C, of manufacturing backpacks is a function of the number, x, of backpacks produced, given by the equation C(x) = 3000 + 20x where C(x) is measured in dollars. Find the cost of producing 500 backpacks.

solution.p: To find the value of C that corresponds to x = \alert{500}, evaluate C(500). C(\alert{500}) = 3000 + 20(\alert{500}) = 13,000 The cost of producing 500 backpacks is 13,000.

subsection.title: Linear Functions
subsection.p:
Linear relationships are relationships in which the rate of change is constant.
Linear Equation
A linear function is a function which has a constant rate of change.
Many phenomena can be modeled using linear functions y = f (x) where the equations have the form f (x) = (\text{starting value}) + (\text{rate of change}) \cdot x. The initial value, or the value of f(0), is the vertical intercept of the graph, and the rate of change is the slope of the graph.
Thus, we can write an equation of a line as f (x) = b + mx where the constant term, b, is the vertical intercept of the line, and m, the coefficient of x, is the slope of the line. This form for an equation of a line is called the slope-intercept formslope-intercept form.

assemblage.title: Slope-Intercept Form
assemblage.p: If we write an equation of a linear function in the form, f (x) = b + mx then m is the slopeslope of the line, and b is the vertical intercept.

subsection.p: (You may have encountered the slope-intercept equation in the equivalent form y = mx + b.)

For example, consider the two linear functions and their graphs shown in and .
f (x) = 10 - 3x
\hphantom{00}x\hphantom{00} \hphantom{0}f(x)\hphantom{0}
0 10
1 7
2 4
3 1
4 -2
deceasing line
g(x) = -3+2x
\hphantom{00}x\hphantom{00} \hphantom{0}f(x)\hphantom{0}
0 -3
1 -1
2 1
3 3
4 5
inceasing line

Some observations:
We can see that the vertical intercept of each line is given by the constant term, b.
By examining the table of values, we can also see why the coefficient of xgives the slope of the line:
For f (x), each time x increases by 1 unit, y decreases by 3 units.
For g(x), each time x increases by 1 unit, y increases by 2 units.
For each graph, the coefficient of x is a scale factor that tells us how many units y changes for 1 unit increase in x. But that is exactly what the slope tells us about a line.

Is is also useful to introduce the term x-intercept at this point. x-intercept
An x-intercept for a function f(x) is the value of x such that f(x)=0.

statement.p:
Francine is choosing an Internet service provider. She paid 30 for a modem, and she is considering three companies for service:
Juno charges 14.95 per month,
ISP.com charges 12.95 per month,
and peoplepc charges 15.95 per month. Match the graphs in to Francine’s Internet cost with each company.

solution.p: Francine pays the same initial amount, 30 for the modem, under each plan. The monthly fee is the rate of change of her total cost, in dollars per month. We can write a formula for her cost under each plan.

sidebyside.p: \text{Juno: } f(x) = 30 + 14.95x \text{ISP.com: } g(x) = 30 + 12.95x \text{peoplepc: } h(x) = 30 + 15.95x The graphs of these three functions all have the same y-intercept, but their slopes are determined by the monthly fees. The steepest graph, III, is the one with the largest monthly fee, peoplepc, and ISP.com, which has the lowest monthly fee, has the least steep graph, I.

note.p: In the equation f (x) = b + mx, we call m and b parametersparameters. Their values are fixed for any particular linear equation; for example, in the equation y = 2x + 3, m = 2 and b = 3, and the variables are x and y. By changing the values of m and b, we can write the equation for any line except a vertical line (see ). The collection of all linear functions f (x) = b + mx is called a two-parametertwo-parameter family of functions.

image.description: lines with common intercept or common slope

subsection.title: Describing Functions
subsection.p: There are several terms that will be useful in describing functions. We first begin with the notion of an increasing function.

assemblage.title: Increasing Function
assemblage.p:
A function $f$ is increasing if the values of $f(x)$ increase as $x$ increases.
The graph of an increasing function climbs as we move from left to right.

assemblage.title: Decreasing Function
assemblage.p:
A function f is decreasing if the values of f(x) decrease as x increases.
The graph of a decreasing function falls as we move from left to right.

p.em: A function f(x) is monotonic if it increases for all x or decreases for all x.

assemblage.title: Directly Proportional
assemblage.p: We say y is directly proportional to x if there is a nonzero constant k such that, y = kx. This k is called the constant of proportionality.

assemblage.title: Inversely Proportional
assemblage.p: We say that y is inversely proportional to x if y is proportional to the reciprocal of x, that is, y = k/x for a nonzero constant k.
